title: Army Releases Heavily Redacted Report On Arlington Cemetery Altercation
content:
The Department of Defense (DOD) and Army released a report Friday disclosing the details of an altercation that occurred during former President Donald Trumpâ€™s August visit to Arlington National Cemetery.
Trump honored the 13 American service members killed during President Joe Bidenâ€™s August 2021 Afghanistan withdrawal on the three-year anniversary of the incident at a ceremony that later became controversial when reports surfaced that a physical altercation had occurred between a campaign official and an Arlington National Cemetery staffer over photo restrictions. The agency released the report in response to a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request from American Oversight but details a multitude of exemptions to the request including laws protecting inter- and intra-agency communications and records pertaining to an ongoing investigation, leaving the report heavily redacted.
The report labeled the event a â€œsimple assaultâ€ and said an action occurred with â€œboth of [redacted] hands while attempting to move pastâ€ but that no medical attention was necessary following the incident. The documents contain a sworn affidavit taken at the time of the altercation but is entirely redacted, including the name of who gave the statement.
The individual involved chose not to press charges following the incident, the report says.
The incident occurred after a cemetery staff member attempted to enforce a rule prohibiting political activity and â€œwas abruptly pushed asideâ€ by a Trump campaign official, according to NPR.
â€œParticipants in the August 26th ceremony and the subsequent Section 60 visit were made aware of federal laws, Army regulations and DoD policies, which clearly prohibit political activities on cemetery grounds,â€ the Army said in a statement after the incident, according to NPR. â€œAn ANC employee who attempted to ensure adherence to these rules was abruptly pushed aside. Consistent with the decorum expected at ANC, this employee acted with professionalism and avoided further disruption. The incident was reported to the JBM-HH police department, but the employee subsequently decided not to press charges. Therefore, the Army considers this matter closed.â€
Vice President Kamala Harris criticized Trump over the event, stating that the former president did not honor service members â€” a claim which several Gold Star families quickly rebuked by placing blame instead on Harris for her apparent lack of acknowledgment of the incident that killed the soldiers. The families requested Trump attend the event and take photos with them, Trump stated in a Truth Social post, and the families later confirmed to the Daily Caller. (EXCLUSIVE: Army Hit With Lawsuit After Stonewalling Inquiries Into West Pointâ€™s Removal Of Iconic Mission Statement)
The Army and DOD did not immediately respond to the Daily Caller News Foundationâ€™s request for comment.

title: Soros-Funded Group Backs Maricopa DA Candidate Who Helped Murder Accomplice Evade Child Sexual Abuse Charges
content:
The Democrat running for Maricopa County District Attorney previously defended a man indicted of sexually assaulting a mentally disabled child by suggesting that the 12-year-old girl made the story up for attention â€” and has managed to snag an endorsement from Soros-backed advocacy group.
In 2009, Tamika Wooten became Jacob Payneâ€™s criminal defense attorney after he was accused of repeatedly sexually assaulting a child, court records show. Before Wooten represented him, Payne pled guilty to kidnapping in 2004 after he admitted to restraining a 19-year-old girl as an accomplice murdered her, receiving five years in prison for his crime. Wooten, while representing Payne in 2009, said that â€œchildren with learning disabilities fabricate stories to get attentionâ€ to discredit the young girl who accused the freshly-released convict of assaulting her.
Wooten, who is running a platform of putting fewer criminals in jail by prioritizing â€œalternatives to incarceration,â€ secured the endorsement of Our Vote Our Voice Arizona on Sept. 20. The Soros familyâ€™s Open Society Action Fund in 2023 gave just over $1 million to the group, a significant sum for an organization that has had an average annual revenue of roughly $2.5 million since 2020, according to tax documents. (Stream The Daily Callerâ€™s Documentary â€˜Lawlessâ€™ HERE)
The girl who accused Payne of sexual assault claimed that he had repeatedly groped her and forced her to engage in sex acts, according to court filings. Hospital staff found blood on her underwear after one such assault â€” she had not been menstruating at the time, per police testimony.
Three of the girlâ€™s siblings told the officer who arrested Payne that they had witnessed their sister come out of the room Payne was in while buttoning up her pants, according to court filings. The girlâ€™s older brother called their mother and told her that his sister had been molested. When confronted by the girlâ€™s mother over the phone, Payne hung up and attempted to flee the apartment.
Wooten, who moved to stop prosecutors from referring to Payne as a â€œpredatorâ€ or â€œpedophile,â€ argued that the girlâ€™s family members may have â€œcoachedâ€ her into accusing him of assault because of their â€œdislikeâ€ for the man, court documents show. Wooten also said that the young girlâ€™s inability to remember specific details about the assaults was evidence of her fabricating the story.
The girl had previously made a false sexual assault claim against her father, which led her mother to initially dismiss her allegation against Payne. Her mother took her daughter seriously after her siblings corroborated her claims.
The jury ultimately found Payne not guilty.
Payne was indicted of sexually abusing a child again in 2013, this time being accused of molesting a six-year-old girl, according to court records. Prosecutors ultimately dropped the charges â€œin the interest of justiceâ€ but explicitly noted that their decision was not made because evidence was insufficient. He pled guilty to aggravated assault in 2020 and was then convicted of disseminating nude images he took of a woman without her consent in 2023.
The Soros family has made a broad effort to reform criminal justice in the United States away from incarceration and toward rehabilitation, spending tens of millions on criminal justice nonprofits and on electing left-wing prosecutors. Many large cities where the Soros network worked to install prosecutors aligned with their views saw considerable upticks in crime.

Our Voice Our Vote Arizona and Wooten did not immediately respond to the Daily Caller News Foundationâ€™s requests for comment.

title: â€˜Greatest White Man That Ever Livedâ€™: Charlamagne Claims â€˜Trump Has Even Defied The Laws Of White Privilegeâ€™
content:

title: California Dems In Tight House Races Back Tough-On-Crime Ballot Measure That Newsom Opposes
content:
California Democrats in tight House races are backing a crime ballot measure despite Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom strongly opposing the initiative, according to the Los Angeles Times Thursday.
Although Newsom fiercely opposes Proposition 36, which increases penalties for retail and drug crimes, many Democrats in tight House races have thrown their support behind the measure, according to the L.A. Times. Proposition 36 is popular with the majority of Californians, with 73% of voters supporting the measure, according to a Public Policy Institute of California (PPIC) poll conducted Oct. 7 to Oct. 15.
Newsom said the measure would cause â€œmass incarcerationâ€ and that it was an â€œinsult,â€ according to the San Francisco Chronicle. However, he also said that he does not have the â€œbandwidthâ€ to actively campaign against the measure, according to the Sacramento Bee Sept. 20.
â€œI would think that a Republican opponent would love it if a Democratic candidate opposed Prop. 36 because it would make it very easy for them to paint them as soft on crime,â€ Jared Sichel, political strategist for Republican, conservative and independent candidates in Orange County told the Los Angeles Times. â€œIf you are a Democrat that is opposed to Prop. 36, that will hurt you in November.â€ (RELATED: California Keeps Driving Up Gas Prices With â€˜Layers And Layersâ€™ Of Green Rules And Regs)
Democratic House candidates who support Proposition 36 include Adam Gray in the 13th Congressional district, Will Rollins in the 41st district, Derek Tran in the 46th district, Rudy Salas in the 22nd district and Joe Kerr in the 40th district, according to the L.A. Times. Most of the races take place in districts with a â€œhealthy mix of Republicans and Democrats,â€ Sichel told the L.A. Times.
For example, the 13th district race between Gray and Republican Scott Baugh is within 3 points, according to a WPA Intelligence poll published Oct. 20. The race for the 22nd district between Salas and Republican incumbent David Valadao is currently tied, according to a September Emerson College poll.
Proposition 36 comes in the wake of discontent with the results of the 2014 Proposition 47, which downgraded the penalties for drug possession and theft under $950 from felonies to misdemeanors. The incarceration rate fell 8% the two years after Proposition 47 passed, according to a September PPIC study.
Crime has been a persistent issue in the state, with overall crime up 1.7% in 2023 and up 15.4% since 2019, according to the PPIC. Out of all property crimes reported in 2023, 63% were larceny theft, 15% were burglaries and 22% were auto thefts.
The homeless population in California grew from 118,552 in 2013 to 181,399 in 2023. The number of camps in San Francisco reached its highest point since 2020 of 523 sites recorded in September 2023.
Proposition 36 would largely roll back Proposition 47â€™s reforms, upgrading drug possession and theft under $950 to felonies. It would also increase jail time for repeat retail theft, and make the possession of fentanyl a felony.
â€œI fear I canâ€™t do everything. Iâ€™ve got, trying to get Kamala Harris elected President of the United States, trying to get through these 900 bills,â€ Newsom said in a Sept. 19 press conference according to the Bee. â€œI just pray, I really do, that people take a good look at Proposition 36.â€
Newsomâ€™s office did not immediately respond to the Daily Caller News Foundationâ€™s request for comment.

title: Kamalaâ€™s Last-Ditch Pitch To Black Men Is A Dream For Scammers, Fraudsters
content:
Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™s plan to offer $20,000 in forgivable loans to minority entrepreneurs is a golden opportunity for scammers and fraudsters, experts told the Daily Caller.
Harris announced the plan in early October as part of her â€œOpportunity Agenda for Black Men.â€ It promises to â€œensure that Black men can build wealth and achieve economic successâ€ by providing one million loans, fully forgivable and worth up to $20,000 each, to black entrepreneurs â€œand others who have historically faced barriers to starting a new business or growing an existing business.â€
The loans would be in partnership with the Small Business Administration (SBA), which also oversaw the administration of the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), a COVID-era program meant to give small businesses resources â€œto maintain their payroll, hire back employees who may have been laid off, and cover applicable overhead.â€
That program, however, was the target of a sprawling fraud scheme which was â€œthe single largest transfer of money to criminal groups in our history,â€ Haywood Talcove, the CEO of LexisNexis Risk Solutions Government, told the Daily Caller.
The rate of fraud under COVID-era payment plans like PPP was â€œconservatively 20 percentâ€ and â€œprobably closer to 35 percent,â€ Talcove told the Caller. Given the efforts of large transnational criminal organizations, Talcove said, it could be as high as 50 percent. If Harrisâ€™s plan saw similar rates of fraud, it would cost the taxpayer billions of dollars. (Stream â€˜CLEANING UP KAMALAâ€™ Now)
Of the potentially hundreds of billions of dollars Talcove estimates people stole through COVID programs, the government has only recovered $13 billion, he told the Caller.
In fact, PPP fraud, and exploitation of the similar COVID-19 Economic Injury Disaster Loan (EIDL), has been so rampant that the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee (PRAC) extended the statute of limitation on the crime from five years to 10 in 2023.
In addition to the fraud perpetrated by transnational groups, who Talcove says come from countries like China, Russia, Nigeria and Romania, Americans appeared to exploit COVID relief extensively as well.
The government fully forgave PPP loans that went to alleged businesses such as â€œFree Money LLC,â€ an apparently New York-based company who had $15,000 in PPP loans forgiven in 2021, according to Pro Publica. (RELATED: Man Sentenced To 9 Years In Prison After Fraudulently Using $1.6 Million In PPP Loans On Cars, Rolex)
Other eyebrow-raising corporations to receive forgiveness included â€œMoney Makes Money Inc.â€ and â€œNig Corp.â€
Something like this? https://t.co/HUFW4dCpqg pic.twitter.com/wC8HzzTj5h

In 2023, the PRAC also found 69,323 potentially ineligible social security numbers who had received PPP loans, according to a report.
Harrisâ€™s new plan appears just as likely to fall victim to exploitation.
â€œAnytime you have a government-sponsored subsidy that is going to a massive amount of people, the probability for improper payments and fraud is 100 percent,â€ Talcove said.
â€œHistory has shown us that when big sums of money are quickly rolled out with inadequate oversight, we open the door to fraud and abuse,â€ Republican Texas Rep. Michael Cloud told the Daily Caller.
Criminals are already talking about how theyâ€™re going to exploit the program on platforms like Telegram, Talcove said.
Twitter users have also been quick to point out how easily they believe it will be to defraud the government.
â€œI think Kamala Harris just announced we can run the PPP loan scam again if she get in office,â€ one user wrote.

â€œ$20,000 isnâ€™t even enough money to launch a food truck, but it is just the right amount to buy a used car or nice vacation while being too small to justify any serious investigation into its misuse,â€ another said.
$20,000 isnâ€™t even enough money to launch a food truck, but it is just the right amount to buy a used car or nice vacation while being too small to justify any serious investigation into its misuse. https://t.co/NYCH1yWf7m

The federal government has taken almost no responsibility for the fraud.
Republican Kentucky Rep. James Comer and the House Oversight Committee, which Rep. Cloud is a member of, did probe COVID fraud and found close to $200 billion in stolen funds.
I will get the backs of Americaâ€™s taxpayers.
That is why on February 1, @GOPoversight will hold our first hearing titled â€œFederal Pandemic Spending: A Prescription for Waste, Fraud, and Abuse,â€ to focus on the rampant waste of taxpayer $$$ in COVID relief programs. @BloombergTV pic.twitter.com/WZWhsrhyrK
â€” Rep. James Comer (@RepJamesComer) January 28, 2023
â€œThe Biden-Harris Administration allowed fraud to run rampant in federal unemployment programs and is now moving fast to make the pandemic unemployment programs permanent,â€ Comer wrote in a report.
Despite the committeeâ€™s recommendations, which include prioritizing antiquated IT systems and verifying claimantsâ€™ proof of work, there is still a lack of federal accountability for the programs, Cloud told the Caller.
â€œA forgivable loan theoretically comes with conditions that must be met, such as job creation or measurable contributions to the economy, to be forgiven. In practice, though, many of these programs end up functioning like handouts because they lack the rigorous oversight needed to ensure real accountability,â€ Cloud said.
Talcove concurred. (RELATED: â€˜Riggedâ€™: Death Of The American Voter | WATCH NOW)
â€œWhen thereâ€™s an emergency, like there was with COVID, [the government says] weâ€™ll go get the money later. Weâ€™ll stop the criminals later, right? But the fact of the matter is, pay and chase, it doesnâ€™t work.â€
â€œNo one ever talks about the victim,â€ Talcove, who told the Caller his mother was a victim of stolen identity, said. â€œThese are not victimless crimes. Thereâ€™s somebody that needed the benefit, whose identity was purchased on the dark web for pennies that couldnâ€™t get what they deserved.â€
In addition to being vulnerable to fraud, Harrisâ€™ race-based plan is also â€œunconstitutional,â€ Rep. Cloud said.
â€œ[Itâ€™s] a ridiculous thing to propose when our country is currently incredibly divided and all Americans are struggling to afford essentials under her administration,â€ he said.

title: EXCLUSIVE: â€˜A Planned Terror Attackâ€™: House Republicans Target DHS For Accommodating Lebanese Nationals
content:
Republican Texas Rep. The Daily Caller first obtained a copy of the letter, in which Babin and eleven other House Republicans condemn the Biden-Harris administration for their announcement of new actions to provide an immigration â€œreprieveâ€ to Lebanese nationals and individuals having no nationality who last resided in Lebanon.
â€œWhile Israel is suffering weekly rocket bombardments from terrorists in Lebanon, the Biden-Harris administration has not only foolishly decided to hamstring our ability to deport Lebanese aliens, including those here illegally, but also offer them immigration benefits and work authorization. Just weeks ago, an ISIS terrorist â€“ who this administration failed to properly vet and welcomed into our country with open arms â€“ was caught planning an Election Day attack,â€ Babin told the Daily Caller. title: District Attorney Facing Recall Vote Backed Halting Death Penalty For Man Convicted Of Torturing, Killing Infant
content:
A district attorney facing a recall vote in November backed removing a man from death row who was convicted of torturing and murdering an infant, according to the San Francisco Chronicle Thursday.
Alameda County District Attorney Pamela Price, who has received financial backing from left-wing billionaire George Soros, got Superior Court Judge Thomas Stevens on Oct. 14 to spare convict Michael Lopezâ€™s life, giving him a lighter sentence, according to the Chronicle. His punishment was initially the death penalty for first-degree murder and torture after he was convicted in 2001, but it was reduced to 26 years to life for second-degree murder and lewd act on a child with a great bodily injury enhancement.
Deputy District Attorney Aimee Solway, who works in Priceâ€™s office, asked for the resentencing â€œin the interest of justice,â€ according to the Chronicle. Lopez, since he was arrested in 1999 and would have his current time in prison counted towards his sentence, may be eligible for parole if officials deem him worthy. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: House Oversight Republicans Demand Answers From FBI Over Revised Crime Stats)
Solway claimed in the most recent motion that prosecutors excluded jurors on the basis of race, that the case wasnâ€™t consistent with past death penalty cases and that Lopezâ€™s low IQ couldâ€™ve impacted his ability to care for the child, according to the Chronicle. He also cited Lopezâ€™s clean disciplinary record in prison and the low likelihood that he would commit future crimes.
This is the fourth time Price asked Lopez to be resentenced, according to the Chronicle. Price promised when she was elected in 2022 to do away with the death penalty.
Price is currently facing a recall election as crime in the county continues to surge under her tenure, with violent incidents spiking in Oakland, the countyâ€™s largest city, by 21% during just the first ten months she was in office.
Current polling shows the recall effort remains close, with 41% supporting her and 37% supporting the recall, with a 4.9% margin of error, according to a July Binder research poll. Additionally, the recall campaign is outspending the anti-recall effort by over a three-to-one margin, according to KQED.
â€œIn recommending this resentencing, the People in no way diminish the horror, pain and suffering which this child endured,â€ Solway said according to court documents obtained by the Chronicle.
Priceâ€™s office did not immediately respond to the Daily Caller News Foundationâ€™s request for comment.

title: â€˜Donâ€™t Have The Numbersâ€™: Victor Davis Hanson Explains Why He Thinks Dems Are â€˜Depressed,â€™ â€˜Angryâ€™ About Harrisâ€™ Polls
content:
Hoover Institute Senior Fellow Victor Davis Hanson said Friday on his podcast that he believes Democrats are feeling more depressed and angry than usual because they fear they could be losing.
Polls between former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris have tightened with fewer than five days until Election Day. On â€œThe Victor Davis Hanson Show,â€ the senior fellow called out a recent take from CNNâ€™s senior reporter Harry Enten for claiming election polling could be underestimating Harris and noted that her campaign has shifted its resources from North Carolina to Virginia in search of a path to 270 electoral votes.
â€œMy point is that I think thatâ€™s a standard response when they look at those internal polls. Now, why would I say that? They wouldnâ€™t be shifting resources from North Carolina to Virginia,â€ Hanson said. â€œTheyâ€™re ahead in Virginia, but if they were shifting resources from North Carolina to Virginia, then it would be because theyâ€™re behind in Virginia and theyâ€™re ahead, so far ahead in North Carolina, they donâ€™t need it.â€
â€œNo, theyâ€™re shifting it because theyâ€™re behind in North Carolina, and their internal polls say they canâ€™t win it. And I mean, internal polls that are specific, Latino groups, black groups, Asian women, men,â€ Hanson added. â€œThey donâ€™t have the numbers that they need to win that. So then they look at Virginia, and they have an alternate pathway to 270 and Virginia is absolutely central. While theyâ€™re still ahead, at the rate theyâ€™re losing in seven days, they will lose that state. So theyâ€™re putting resources in there.â€
Hanson continued to state that while he believes Democrats like MSNBC hosts Mika Brzezinski, Joe Scarborough and Joy Reid are always angry, their anger has increased over the election despite Harrisâ€™ campaign message first centering on joy. (RELATED: â€˜Whatever It Takesâ€™: Political Strategist Says Dems Must Quit Coddling Biden Just To Make Him Feel â€˜Includedâ€™)

They didnâ€™t, you know, even if you were out there and feel that the mail-in balloting, they master and they have machinations that will help them, they wouldnâ€™t be just so depressed. They are depressed, they really are, and theyâ€™re angry,â€ Hanson said.
â€œYou look at Brzezinski , you look at Joe Scarborough, her husband â€¦ then you look at Joy Reid, you look at Rachel Maddow and then you look at the [View] â€” theyâ€™re all angry. I mean, theyâ€™re angry people anyway, but theyâ€™re just really angry. They have these, they kind of remind me of the people, when they know theyâ€™re losing and theyâ€™re all in a room together and theyâ€™re just, they canâ€™t face reality â€” fantasy,â€ Hanson said. I donâ€™t know if theyâ€™re really losing, but I donâ€™t think that theyâ€™re under-polled. I really donâ€™t.â€
While Trump had once been slightly leading across all seven key wing states in mid-October, Harris gained both Michigan and Wisconsin back over the last week, according to polling averages from RealClearPolitics. title: EXCLUSIVE: Alyssa Farah Encouraged Cassidy Hutchinson To Leak To Reporters Amid Investigation
content:
Former Trump administration official Alyssa Farah Griffin suggested to star Jan. 6 investigation witness Cassidy Hutchinson that she leak to the media while the investigation was ongoing, texts obtained exclusively by the Daily Caller reveal.
Farah, a former Pentagon press secretary during the Trump administration, twice suggested to Hutchinson during active legal proceedings that she should give information to reporters. The pair also discussed ways to circumvent Hutchinsonâ€™s lawyer, Stefan Passantino, to communicate with former Republican Wyoming Rep. Liz Cheney and the Jan. 6 committee, as first reported by Just The News.
â€œThe alternative would be to just say fuck it and give it all to a reporter. Lol,â€ Farah texted Hutchinson after the latter asked if Cheney was still interested in working with her.
Shortly thereafter, in texts exclusively obtained by the Caller, Farah suggested that Hutchinson could coordinate with the committee to strategically leak some information to the press after testifying: â€œBtw, another idea.you could sit down and share it with the committee but then have the committee shares the big stuff you give them with press before your transcripts come out so it looks like it came from someone else.â€
In later discussions, Hutchinson mentions that she is concerned with how to â€œreconfigureâ€ her â€œreputationâ€ within the media.
Passantino told the Caller he had no suspicions about such activity at the time and confirmed that he had never seen these specific messages between Hutchinson and Farah. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: House Republicans Call Out Cassidy Hutchinsonâ€™s J6 Testimony, Threaten Subpoena If She Does Not Produce Documents)
â€œThis is the first I am seeing of some of these texts, but everything here is consistent with what I have been saying publicly and alleging in the various lawsuits I have filed over the past 18 months. I am surprised and pleased to see the facts coming to light,â€ Passantino told the Caller. (RELATED: iPhone Screenshot Undermines Cassidy Hutchisonâ€™s Claim That She Never Dated Matt Gaetz)
Hutchinson began the conversation by asking about a previous discussion the two apparently had, and if Farah had â€œtouched baseâ€ with anyone about it.
â€œHey! Yes. So I reached out to Liz. She agreed to keep our convo totally confidential. She said she admires you, and could tell that you wanted to the right thing from your testimony. Her one concern was so long ad you have counsel, she canâ€™t really ethically talk to you without him. But what she suggests is a follow up with you, with your lawyer thats he and Dan George can lead. Probably can do without other members and Tim Does that help at all? I can tell she really wants to work with you and is just tryin to figure out the right way to do it,â€ Farah responded.
â€œI mean, do you think this is actually of interest to her at this point or is it moot Like have they moved beyond it,â€ Hutchinson replied.
â€œOh itâ€™s very much of interest. She basically just wants to structure it in a way you are comfortable and wants to make sure itâ€™s clear, if you speak to them again, itâ€™s them asking, not you, so you donâ€™t get in trouble with trump world,â€ Farah said. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: House Republicans Demand Comms Between Cassidy Hutchinson, Fani Willisâ€™ Office For J6 Investigation)
Hutchinson then described having trouble getting in touch with her attorney, before they discuss the prospect of leaking information to a reporter.
â€œMy patience is razor thin,â€ Hutchinson said.
â€œDo you think your lawyer would drop you? I feel like you could represent yourself,â€ Farah asked.
â€œI never signed anything I asked several and he said it wasnâ€™t necessary,that they had it taken care of So from a legal pov Iâ€™m not sure? But Iâ€™d assume??â€ Hutchinson responded.
â€œI just looked. I texted him Sunday morning to talk, he said heâ€™d call that afternoon or Monday morning. Thatâ€™s the last I heard from him despite following up every day since,â€ Hutchinson continued. â€œAm I overthinking this??â€
â€œIâ€™m sorry Iâ€™m not trying to be a nuisance,â€ she added.
Farah said she wanted Hutchinson to â€œbe freeâ€ of the situation and proposed that she could potentially get immunity before sharing information with Cheney and the committee.
Hutchinson then asked if she may be asked to testify live.
â€œShe was very clear theyâ€™d want to talk to you behind closed doors at least one more time before theyâ€™d put you up publicly,â€ Farah replied.
Hutchinson then asked if the committee would ask her to come back for more questioning, and claimed that Passantino would tell her to â€œgo F myselfâ€ if she volunteered to do so.
â€œOk thatâ€™s a good question. She was thinking sheâ€™d just ask you back for additional questions. But you probably donâ€™t want them to go through Stefan? She is open to doing this anyway thatâ€™s like ethical/ legal,â€ Farah responded.
Farah went on to propose that her own lawyer may be willing to take on Hutchinsonâ€™s representation pro bono.
Days later, Hutchinson asked Farah to call her â€œasapâ€ after she spoke to Passantino.
â€œdg called him Friday and asked about me coming in. Stephan gave me the weekend â€˜to think on itâ€™ He just said we will comply but heâ€™s going to push back,â€ Hutchinson told Farah. â€œdgâ€ seemingly refers to Dan George, a lawyer for the committee.
â€œHmm ok. That was definitely at Lizâ€™s direction. How do you feel about just doing it with Stefan but answering more questions? You can handle yourself and heâ€™s just there as a figurehead,â€ Farah responded.
â€œAnd basically give ultimatum of a) weâ€™ll come back but we need assurance she wonâ€™t be called in live (which I donâ€™t think theyâ€™ll give) OR b) if you wonâ€™t give us an assurance, re-issue a subpoena,â€ Hutchinson said.
â€œHeâ€™s not against me complying. Heâ€™s actually sort of willing to do it be he thinks it builds my credibility as a witness. But he wants just enough from the committee to balance out the public backlash from the lawsuit and to frame me as super compliant/respectful of congressional subpoenas,â€ she continued.
â€œHeâ€™s going to call dan George this afternoon. Can you tip off Liz or Dan? And see their thoughts?,â€ Hutchinson asked Farah.
â€œIâ€™m personally fine w just Liz and dan but I have a feeling heâ€™ll want it structurally the same as my other Depos. But I havenâ€™t gotten that far w him,â€ Hutchinson said.
â€œDoes that make sense,â€ she asked.
â€œYeah that all makes sense. I actually agree with Stefanâ€™s approach and think itâ€™s accomplished everyoneâ€™s goals. I am happy to tip liz off. And for what itâ€™s worth I donâ€™t think you are close to front in line to testify live But it might be worth asking for the commitment,â€ Farah responded.
â€œMy guess is Stefan cares about protecting trump. Youâ€™re issues were more with meadows and folks around him. And you were simply being honest,â€ she added.
â€œExactly. He doesnâ€™t want me to stonewall the committee now, over this. I think he wants to balance the perception in Trump world if I just go back voluntarily vs. under subpoena,â€ Hutchinson said.
â€œBut heâ€™s probably going to be a bit less friendly to DG when he talks to him. He prob wonâ€™t outright tell him to re-subpoena me, so it may be helpful for DG to throw in (if theyâ€™d do that) â€˜well if you donâ€™t voluntarily come in, weâ€™re likely reissue a subpoenaâ€™,â€ she added.
Hutchinson said their agreed-upon approach could help to â€œreconfigureâ€ her â€œreputationâ€ in the press. She then asked Farah to pass information to Cheney that her and her former lawyer do not plan to fight a subpoena, but that Passantino wants the committee to think they will.
â€œHe talked to DG. Convo was consistent w/ what we discussed. SP told him weâ€™ll need a subpoena to comply, but will â€˜need to decide whether weâ€™re going to fight it.â€™ (Weâ€™re def not going to fight it, but he wants the committee to think we will). Ir case you want to pass to LC or DG,â€ Hutchinson said.
Weeks later, Hutchinson texted Farah she felt like she could â€œdrink myself into a coma.â€
â€œLike I could drink myself into a coma,â€ Hutchinson responded. Farah said she thought the committee would make her testify live.
â€œReally?,â€ Hutchinson asked.
Hutchinson made headlines after testifying before the Jan. 6 committee. She claimed former President Donald Trump lunged for the steering wheel to reroute his car to the Capitol where protesters were gathering on Jan. 6. Sources close to the Secret Service have denied her claims. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: Cassidy Hutchinson Begged Senior Trump Officials For â€˜Financial Assistanceâ€™ After Being Subpoenaed By J6 Committee)
Hutchinson called the Jan. 6 committee â€œbsâ€ in a text message obtained exclusively by the Caller and also begged former senior Trump officials for financial assistance and legal help in February 2022 after she was subpoenaed by the committee. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: Text Messages Show Cassidy Hutchinson Referring To January 6 Committee As â€˜BSâ€™)
Hutchinson did not respond to a request for comment.
Editorâ€™s Note: This article was updated to clarify which texts were obtained exclusively by the Daily Caller.

title: Kamala Harris Calls Trump â€˜Fascistâ€™ In CNN Town Hall
content:
Vice President Kamala Harris said Wednesday in a CNN town hall less than two weeks from the election that she thinks former President Donald Trump is a fascist.
CNNâ€™s Anderson Cooper asked the vice president if she believed Trump was a fascist, pointing to Harrisâ€™ earlier remarks on several articles quoting former chief of staff John Kelly, who warned that the former president would rule as such in a second term. In her response, the vice president cited Kelly and former Trump officialsâ€™ comments who have previously warned about how Trump would act in a second term. (RELATED: Biden Campaigns On Trump Being A Threat To Democracy, But Voters May Not Be Buying It: POLL)
â€œYou quoted General Milly calling Trump a fascist. You yourself have not used that word to describe him. Let me ask you tonight, do you think Donald Trump is a fascist?â€ Cooper asked.
â€œYes I do,â€ Harris said without hesitation. â€œAnd I also believe that the people who know him best on this subject should be trusted.â€
.@andersoncooper asks Harris: Do you think Trump is a fascist?
Harris: Yes.
Her full answer citing Milley, John Kelly, and other former Trump officials who are warning about him. pic.twitter.com/Uw8Rwiwms5
â€” Alex Thompson (@AlexThomp) October 24, 2024
Both the New York Times and The Atlantic both published stories Tuesday, where Kelly claimed that the former president would rule like a fascist, said Hitler â€œdid some good thingsâ€ and wanted generals like the Nazi dictator. The Trump campaign denied the content of both stories.
More content of The Atlantic story has since been called into question. In addition to Kellyâ€™s comments, the story also alleges that the former president disparaged a deceased veteran and her family. Both the Trump campaign, former officials to the president, the deceased veteranâ€™s family and their lawyer have all gone on the record to deny the story.
â€œAfter having dealt with hundreds of reporters in my legal career, this is unfortunately the first time I have to go on record and call out Jeffrey Goldberg@the Atlantic: not only did he misrepresent our conversation but he outright LIED in HIS sensational story,â€ the familyâ€™s lawyer, Natalie Khawam, tweeted.
â€œI need the kind of generals that Hitler hadâ€: Trumpâ€™s obsession with dictators and disdain for Americaâ€™s military are deepening, @JeffreyGoldberg reports: https://t.co/iyB2jrn3sG
â€” The Atlantic (@TheAtlantic) October 22, 2024
Harris gave an unexpected address from her residence Wednesday to address the stories about her opponent.
â€œAll of this is further evidence for the American people of who Donald Trump really is,â€ Harris said. â€œThis is a window into who Donald Trump really is, from the people who know him best. From the people who worked with him side by side, in the Oval Office and in the Situation Room.
â€œIt is clear from John Kellyâ€™s words that Donald Trump is someone who, I quote, â€˜certainly falls into the general definition of fascist.â€™ Who vowed to be a dictator on day one and vowed to use the military as his personal militia to carry out his personal and political vendettas,â€ she continued.
Shortly after the vice presidentâ€™s remarks, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said that President Joe Biden also thought Trump was a fascist.
â€œYou have heard from this president over and over again about the threats to democracy,â€ Jean-Pierre said. â€œAnd the president has spoken about that. You have heard from the former president himself, saying that he is going to be a dictator on day one. This is him, not us, this is him. And itâ€™s not just us the White House saying this, youâ€™ve heard it from officials, former officials who worked for the former president say this as well. So, you know, do we agree , I know that [Vice President Kamala Harris] just spoke about this, do we agree about that determination, yes, we do.â€

title: â€˜Difficult For Her To Winâ€™: Mark Halperin Says â€˜Data Everywhereâ€™ Shows â€˜Things Have Moved In Trumpâ€™s Directionâ€™
content:
Journalist Mark Halperin said Friday that mounting â€œdataâ€ suggests former President Donald Trump is gaining momentum against Vice President Kamala Harris.
Harris currently trails Trump slightly in all seven top swing states, according to the RealClear Polling averages. Halperin, on his 2WAY platform, noted a lack of confidence among Democrats as Harrisâ€™ likelihood of defeating Trump in November appears unlikely. (RELATED: Biden Campaigns On Trump Being A Threat To Democracy, But Voters May Not Be Buying It: POLL)
WATCH:
â€œUnfortunately for blue America, thereâ€™s an asymmetry in whatâ€™s going on now. We could spend all day, the three of us, trying to get a Democrat on the phone who was super confident, like, â€˜Weâ€™re going to win.â€™ We wouldnâ€™t succeed in terms of political professionals, members of Congress, strategists,â€ Halperin said.â€ It would take us one call, random dial any Republican in our rolodex, to find someone who said, â€˜Yeah, Iâ€™m pretty confident weâ€™re going to win.â€™ Or more.â€
â€œOkay, thatâ€™s an asymmetry. Itâ€™s just a reality. Some attribute it to cultural differences between the party and thereâ€™s something to that,â€ he continued. â€œThereâ€™s qualitative and quantitative data everywhere you look that things have moved in Trumpâ€™s direction and that it will be difficult for her to win, but not impossible. And that is causing a lot of tension in blue America.â€
Halperin then pointed to The New York Times/Siena Collegeâ€™s last national poll of the 2024 election cycle, which the outlet published on Friday and found Trump and Harris tied at 48%. The previous NYT/Siena poll published on Oct. 8 found Harris leading Trump 49% to 46% nationally.
â€œThe conventional wisdom has been, even though it may be false, that if Donald Trump is tied or within a couple points in the national poll, heâ€™s going to win. Now The New York Times says itâ€™s possible that Kamala Harris could win the electoral college and lose the popular vote,â€ Halperin said. â€œAnd weâ€™ve talked about Trump over-performing from last time in the big blue states that could make him a bigger popular vote winner, but still lose the electoral college. Possible.â€
The poll also found Trump drawing 42% of Hispanic voters and 11% of black voters. Halperin read from an X post from CNN senior political analyst Ron Brownstein reacting to the poll, which states it â€œshows Harris basically matching [President Joe] Biden winning 2020â€ percentages among whites, but â€œslippingâ€ among minorities, particularly Latinos.
The analyst asserted this data â€œexplains why less diverse Rustbelt states remain the most plausible path for her, as they were for Biden.â€
The journalist also read from an X post from pollster and former Bill Clinton adviser Mark Penn, which states, â€œ[The Wall Street Journal] and Forbes polls all show 3 to 4 point movements in the direction of Trump in the last few weeks. This is real movement and momentum going into the close. It is still close but this is a substantial move.â€
Halperin also asserted Tuesday that Trump will be elected president on Nov. 5 if the current early voting trajectory â€œcontinues.â€

title: CNNâ€™s Harry Enten Dumps Cold Water On Theory Trump Will â€˜Outperform His Pollsâ€™ For Third Time
content:
CNN senior data reporter Harry Enten on Tuesday suggested that former President Donald Trump is unlikely to â€œoutperform his pollsâ€ for a third consecutive presidential election.
Prominent Trump critics, such as James Carville and Donny Deutsch have voiced concerns that Trump could exceed his projected poll numbers again, as he did in 2016 and 2020, which would increase his chances of defeating Vice President Kamala Harris in their tight race. However, Enten argued on â€œCNN News Centralâ€ that it â€œwould be historically unprecedentedâ€ for polling to â€œunderestimateâ€ Trump for a third time. (RELATED: Prominent Election Expert Suggests Pollsters â€˜Have No Ideaâ€™ If Theyâ€™re Accurately Measuring Trump Support)
WATCH:
â€œIs there any precedent that the polls will underestimate Donald Trump once again? Because thatâ€™s all we hear about, â€˜Oh, Donald Trumpâ€™s going to outperform his polls.â€™ So I went back and checked out whether or not a party outran the polls three presidential election cycles in a row in the key battleground states,â€ Enten told host John Berman. â€œItâ€™s never happened. Itâ€™s never happened. Zero times, zero times since 1972. So if the polls are going to underestimate Donald Trump once again, that would be historically unprecedented.â€
â€œNow maybe you want to make the argument that Donald Trump himself is historically unprecedented. But what normally happens is the pollsters catch on. â€˜Hey, weâ€˜re underestimating, weâ€™re not taking into account some part of the electorate,'â€ he added. â€œThey make adjustments and I think that helps to explain why we have never seen that the same party has been underestimated three times in a row in presidential elections at least over the last 52 years.â€
Several pollsters recently told the Daily Caller News Foundation that they are unconvinced that 2024â€™s surveys will end up accurate. They said that although pollsters are working to avoid under-counting hard-to-reach Trump supporters, forecasting the breakdown of the electorate remains difficult due to the limitations of polling techniques in reaching groups like young men and non-college educated Americans.
â€œDonald Trumpâ€™s best polls in 2020 were eight points better than the poll averages in those states. So there was this idea, this universe, â€˜Hey, maybe the averages are really underestimating Donald Trump,â€ Enten said. â€œThis time around the question that I had was, are there still these polls that may indicate that the averages are really underestimating Donald Trump? This time around thereâ€™s really not the evidence for it.â€
â€œThe best polls for Trump actually only have him running about three points ahead of the polling average in the key Great Lake battleground states versus the eight last time around,â€ he added. â€œSo last time around there was this group of pollsters that said, â€˜Hey, wait a minute, the polling average may be underestimating Donald Trump.â€™ This time around, John, they simply put, do not exist.â€
The data reporter also noted that the average 2022 midterm election poll in the Great Lake battleground states â€œunderestimated Democrats by four points,â€ which could indicate pollsters have â€œbeen making adjustmentsâ€ since 2020.
â€œThe bottom line is this, dear audience and Mr. Berman: I think a lot of folks are sort of counting in that Donald Trump will in fact be underestimated by the polls. But when Iâ€™m looking at the evidence, I think you got to hold on a second,â€ Enten said. â€œMaybe thatâ€™ll happen. Maybe itâ€™ll happen. But I think that there are folks who are underestimating the idea that maybe Kamala Harris will be underestimated by the polls at least a week out.â€
Trump currently holds small leads over Harris in all of the top seven swing states, according to the RealClearPolling average.

title: Judge Declines To Recuse From Trump Assassination Attempt Case
content:
Judge Aileen Cannon declined Tuesday to recuse herself from overseeing the case against the man indicted in former President Donald Trumpâ€™s second assassination attempt.
Ryan Routh, who was indicted in September for attempting to assassinate Trump at his Florida golf course, moved to toss Cannon from the case because she was appointed by Trump, handled his classified documents case and has been spoken of favorably by him.
Cannon noted Tuesday she has â€œno control over what private citizens, members of the media, or public officials or candidates elect to say about me or my judicial rulings.â€
â€œI have never spoken to or met former President Trump except in connection with his required presence at an official judicial proceeding, through counsel,â€ she wrote in the seven-page order. â€œI have no â€˜relationship to the alleged victimâ€™ in any reasonable sense of the phrase.â€
Cannon faced calls for recusal from members of the media while handling the classified documents case, though a motion was never filed. She dismissed the case over special counsel Jack Smithâ€™s unlawful appointment in July. (RELATED: Demsâ€™ Attacks On Judge Overseeing Trump Classified Docs Case Donâ€™t Add Up, Legal Experts Say)
â€œThis case, like the prior cited cases involving former President Trump, were randomly assigned to me through the Clerkâ€™s random case assignment system,â€ Cannon wrote in her order. â€œPeriod. I will not be guided by highly inaccurate, uninformed, or speculative opinions to the contrary.â€
Cannon also wrote that going to high school with one of the prosecutors and attending his wedding nine years ago is not disqualifying.
â€œThis factor does not supply a basis from which a reasonable observer â€” equipped with all of the facts and circumstances â€” would question my impartiality,â€ she wrote.
The government previously opposed Routhâ€™s motion.
â€œRouthâ€™s motion does not cite any authority mandating recusal in these circumstances, and does not present either facts or case law requiring recusal on this record in light of the controlling standard,â€ prosecutors wrote in an Oct. 21 court filing. â€œJudges are obligated to recuse only when there are proper grounds to do so.â€

title: â€˜Sheâ€™s Not Aheadâ€™: Mark Halperin Says Dems â€˜Scratching Their Headsâ€™ Over Harris â€˜Spending The Day In Washingtonâ€™
content:
Newsmax political analyst Mark Halperin said Tuesday that Democrats are questioning Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ decision to stay in Washington, D.C., instead of campaigning in swing states.
Harris will be in Washington, D.C., to conduct interviews with Telemundo and NBC News, which are scheduled to air Tuesday evening, according to Reuters. Halperin, on â€œWake Up America,â€ argued that with Harris trailing former President Donald Trump, the move raises concerns about her campaign strategy. (RELATED: Kamala Harris Used To Think Border Wall Was â€˜Un-American.â€™ Now She Supports It.)
WATCH:
â€œLook, if she loses, thereâ€™ll be a lot of second-guessing of all sorts of decisions they made. And one of them will be what has been a light schedule. If she thinks sheâ€™s ahead â€” her campaign doesnâ€™t think sheâ€™s ahead â€” but if they thought she was ahead, you could say sheâ€™s running out the clock, but sheâ€™s not ahead,â€ Halperin said. â€œAnd so itâ€™s a choice theyâ€™re making. I think a lot of it has to do with the amount of preparation time she wants and requires for the interview sheâ€™s doing today, for the town hall she has coming up, but there is head-scratching amongst Democrats, two weeks to go, someone whoâ€™s fighting for the presidency, and sheâ€™s spending the day in Washington.â€
â€œAgain, a lot of Democrats also scratching their heads. Youâ€™d think it just, you know, jump on the Amtrak and go up to Philadelphia and do something. But the reality is, as Donald Trump proves when he does, you know, national events outside of the battleground states, that NBC News interview will get coverage everywhere,â€ he added. â€œAnd maybe she feels like thatâ€™s going to fill in the news cycle. But, like I said, if she loses, people are going to go over her schedule and wonder why she took so many days in Washington.â€
Democrats, including some of Harrisâ€™ own staffers, recently raised concerns to Politico that the vice presidentâ€™s light campaign schedule could damage the campaign in its final stretch. Trump is currently leading Harris in all of the top seven swing states, according to RealClearPolling averages.
Harris told â€œThe Viewâ€ on Oct. 8 that nothing â€œcomes to mindâ€ when asked how she would govern differently from President Biden, an answer Halperin said damaged her campaign.
â€œThat one answer, I think probably, on balance, net did more harm for her than any good thatâ€™s come out of these interviews,â€ he asserted.

title: Liberal NGO Prepares â€˜Quick Reaction Forcesâ€™ To Respond To Unrest At Election Facilities
content:
Common Defense, a left-leaning non-governmental organization, is preparing a coalition of â€œQuick Reaction Forcesâ€ in order to respond to potential escalation at polling locations, according to NPR.
Ahead of the election, Common Defense, which is made up of 40,000 veterans, is mobilizing its network to help â€œmonitor extremist activity in swing states around the election,â€ according to NPR. After instructing members in â€œopen source intelligenceâ€ to help predict unrest around polling locations, individuals are instructed by the organization to respond to escalation by filming video in an attempt to produce â€œaccountability,â€ the outlet reported. (Stream Daily Callerâ€™s latest documentary â€˜Riggedâ€™ HERE)
â€œWeâ€™re training a lot of folks in de-escalation,â€ Perry Oâ€™Brien, co-founder of Common Defense, told NPR. â€œWeâ€™re training folks in monitoring and capturing video for accountability.â€
When a â€œcrisisâ€ unfolds, the â€œQuick Reaction Forcesâ€ will show up to polling locations â€œunarmed and in plainclothes,â€ the outlet reported.
Common Defense has been teaching members to review publicly accessible information â€” frequently found on social media â€” in a search for potential threats in swing states, Oâ€™Brien told NPR.
â€œThatâ€™s obviously the area that weâ€™re anticipating a lot of these threats are going to come from,â€ he added.
A majority of registered voters, 76%, are concerned about â€œviolence aimed at overturning the election results,â€ according to an AP-NORC poll published Monday. Eighty-two percent are worried about â€œviolence targeting political figures or election officials,â€ the poll shows. (RELATED: Democrats Fight To Make Elections Less Trustworthy)
The Daily Caller spoke to various experts across the political field about what to expect in the event of a Trump victory. From protests, to lawfare, to Secret Service protection, they predicted a more extreme and dangerous response from Democrats in 2024 compared to 2016.
Woman screams â€œNOâ€ as Donald Trump is sworn in as the 45th President of the United States ğŸ˜‚
pic.twitter.com/QDp5uKbWNvâ€” Daily Loud (@DailyLoud) January 28, 2024
â€œIn 2016, I just donâ€™t think that the population was prepared for it, and thatâ€™s why we didnâ€™t see wider-spread unrest, because nobody expected it to happen,â€ Richie McGinniss, a longtime video journalist who has covered social unrest for years, told the Caller. McGinnis was previously the video director for the Daily Caller.
â€œI hate to say it, but itâ€™s going to be a lot worse [in 2024] than it was in 2016 if Trump wins,â€ he added, citing the past several years of â€œanti-Trumpismâ€ that the nation has been steeped in.
The Daily Caller reached out to Common Defense for comment.

title: â€˜Untold Miseryâ€™: Trump Brings Out Gold Star Mother-In-Law, Angel Mom Ahead Of Harris Campaignâ€™s Last Big Event
content:
Republican nominee Donald Trump invited the family members of victims impacted by the policies of the Biden-Harris administration to his press conference Tuesday ahead of Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ major campaign speech in Washington, D.C.
The former president held a press conference at Mar-a-Lago where he invited angel mom Tammy Nobles, who lost her daughter to the brutality of an MS-13 member, and gold star mother-in-law Christy Shamblin who lost her daughter-in-law, Marine Sgt. Nicole Gee, during the botched withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021. The victims came forward to link the tragedies to Harrisâ€™ policies before she gave a major speech at the National Mall Tuesday.
Noblesâ€™ daughter, Kayla Hamilton, died on July 27, 2022, after 17-year-old MS-13 gang member Walter Martinez allegedly raped and strangled her to death with a telephone cord in Aberdeen, Maryland.
â€œI just wanted to say that [the Department of] Homeland Security did not do their job, Health and Human Services did not do their job, the Biden-Harris administration did not do their job,â€ Nobles said. â€œIf they would have done their job, maybe that one phone call to El Salvador, maybe my daughter would still be alive today. Kayla was a very beautiful, young lady inside and out. She was independent, learning to become independent, she had two jobs, she overcame obstacles dealing with autism and was able to find the job that she loved. She loved animals, especially her cat Oreo and she cared about the homeless. She loved God, and she loved going to church and her life was just ripped from her 3 days after she celebrated her 20th birthday.â€
U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) confirmed that Martinez was involved with a violent MS-13 gang and resided in the U.S. illegally, according to WMAR 2 News. He reportedly entered the U.S. through Texas illegally in March 2022 before Border Patrol released him into Maryland to live with a sponsor.
Trump said Harrisâ€™ border and economic policies, along with her actions toward the Afghanistan withdrawal, are â€œdisqualifyingâ€ for her to serve as commander-in-chief.
â€œKamalaâ€™s cruel and immoral actions on our border are actually disqualifying in my opinion. Sheâ€™s unfit, sheâ€™s an unfit person and she knows this is going on,â€ Trump said. â€œShe didnâ€™t call anybody, including the 13 soldiers that were so needlessly killed in Afghanistan with that horrible moment in time when our country just lost all respect from the whole world when that happened â€¦ Kamala has also caused untold misery through her destruction of our economy.â€
Shamblinâ€™s daughter-in-law, Marine Sergeant Gee, was one of the thirteen service members who died during the botched withdrawal of Afghanistan on Aug. 26, 2021, in which Harris had bragged about being the last person in the room during the administrationâ€™s decision to withdraw.
â€œ[Gee] was the cornerstone of a very large family,â€ Shamblin emotionally said. â€œAnd instead of planning family gatherings, and holiday meals, and Christmases and baby showers, our family and thousands of other families plan outings at funeral gravesites and thatâ€™s where we as a family celebrate my daughter-in-law at Arlington National Cemetery because she is in the ground. Her story isnâ€™t unique to our family, sheâ€™s just ours. There are thousands and thousands and thousands of wounded veterans who came home from that war who need our help and who are ignored by our current administration.â€
The former president attended a ceremony honoring the 13 service members on the third anniversary of the withdrawal, while President Joe Biden and Harris were not in attendance.
Federal immigration law under the Biden-Harris administration allows the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to â€œparoleâ€ migrants instead of detaining them for â€œhumanitarian reasons or significant public benefit,â€ which has been challenged by many Republican-led states.
Illegal encounters exceeded 2 million in the 2022, 2023 and 2024 fiscal years, largely surpassing encounters at the U.S.-Mexico border during the Trump administration, according to Customs and Border Protection (CBP).

title: Persistent Polling Issues Could Vindicate Republican â€˜Bloodbathâ€™ Election Prediction
content:
Some Republicans assume former President Donald Trumpâ€™s historic polling underperformance spells a bloodbath for Democrats in November. But the assumptionâ€™s accuracy, according to four center-right analysts, is muddled by new changes in methodology.
These analysts offered some insight into how the numbers might unfold, but conceded thereâ€™ll be no certainty until after Election Day. For them, 2024â€™s polling accuracy boils down to three main factors: demographic overcorrection, response bias and something called â€œrecalled vote weighting.â€
Current battleground aggregates place the former president even or ahead of Vice President Kamala Harris, bolstering Republicans who argue Trump will once again triumph due to polling error. Furthermore, some have taken to comparing recent polling to numbers from the same time during the 2020 and 2016 cycles, which shows Trump polling significantly ahead of his previous runs for president.
Itâ€™s not really that close Nate. https://t.co/oBZxpiWvfR
â€” Chuck Armstrong (@ChuckArmstron11) October 29, 2024
Polling averages placed President Joe Biden, for example, ahead of Trump by 8% in Michigan on Oct. 25, 2020, according to FiveThirtyEight â€” and Biden only won the state by 2.8%.
Harris led Michigan by 0.7% on the same day in 2024. With the same level of polling error, Trump would win the state by 5.1%.
But is it reasonable to expect the same level of polling error in 2024 â€” and Trump to sweep battlegrounds by five points or more?
Trafalgar Group founder Robert Cahaly doubts such dramatic margins, but said he still expects Trump to outperform October polling in an interview with the Caller.
â€œIs that possible?â€ he said. â€œYes, but I think the likelihood is that heâ€™s just going to overperform by about two or three pointsâ€¦ Itâ€™s different in 2024, but we see a significant hidden [Trump] vote. We think that the places Trump is most likely to significantly overperform a poll are probably going to be Arizona and Michigan and Georgia.â€
Trump is slated to outperform polls in these states, Cahaly argues, because his firm has found that undecided voters are breaking for the former president there. He added that pollsters struggle to capture Trump voters because they need to be â€œcajoledâ€ into answering polls and assured of their anonymity, fearing social backlash.
There is some reason to doubt the notion that Trumpâ€™s true standing is so much higher than current numbers suggest; pollsters have identified and rectified many of the sources of their past error, with FiveThirtyEight even touting the 2022 midterm as the most accurately predicted cycle since â€œat least 1998, with almost no bias toward either party.â€
WATCH: DecisionDeskHQ analyst @MichaelPruser debunks the notion that polls suddenly â€œfixedâ€ for the â€œhidden Trump voteâ€ and are thus now â€œaccurate.â€
â€œI have NO confidence, absolutely ZERO confidence, that polling will be correct this year.â€
â€œThe response bias is educated andâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/YPY6cbpr0B
â€” Eric Daugherty (@EricLDaugh) October 27, 2024
â€œThe reason they were really off, in my judgment, in 2016 is that they undercounted non-college-educated whites,â€ author and political consultant Ryan Girdusky told the Caller. â€œThey had an over-response bias of college-educated white liberals.â€
Pollsters generally didnâ€™t account for votersâ€™ education levels in 2016, a data point which hadnâ€™t previously cleaved so sharply along partisan lines, according to a report from the American Association for Public Opinion Research. (RELATED: Trump Leading Harris In Key Swing State Two Weeks Before Election Day, Poll Finds)
Though firms had corrected the education oversight by 2020, polls still significantly underestimated Trumpâ€™s support in that cycle. Girdusky blames this on â€œpartisan response bias,â€ the tendency of certain demographics to answer polls at a higher rate, and said that it could distort predictions for 2024.
â€œIn July, when everybody on the planet was calling on Joe Biden to quit the race because he was going to lose, polls still showed him winning seniors, but he didnâ€™t win them [in 2020],â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s how overly large the response bias is among liberal seniors â€” the people who live to watch Rachel Maddow over and over.â€
Some analysts doubt that the accuracy of 2022 polling necessarily guarantees similarly reliable predictions for 2024.
â€œItâ€™s about the expanse of the electorate,â€ Mark Harris, the co-founder of ColdSpark, a political consulting firm, told the Caller. â€œThe electorate gets much larger in a presidential election year, and the people who come into it are harder to get on the phone.â€
He echoed concerns about response bias, noting that non-college-educated whites, who he said comprise about half of Pennsylvaniaâ€™s electorate, are â€œjust a lot harderâ€ to poll.
But adjusting methodology for greater accuracy isnâ€™t an insurmountable challenge. Private and internal polling, Harris argues, are usually pretty reliable â€” itâ€™s the public pollsters who bear the lionâ€™s share of the blame for past inaccuracies.
Universities and other public pollsters often canâ€™t afford to conduct statewide surveys with large sample sizes, he explained, which forces them to artificially adjust, or â€œweight,â€ responses from under or overrepresented demographics â€” leading to less accurate predictions. Public pollsters also use online surveys, which is less â€œrigorousâ€ than tactics employed by private firms, he argues.
â€œYou could easily have [in a public poll], â€˜Oh, we did 20 interviews with Republican women, and Trumpâ€™s only getting 60% of themâ€¦â€™ Well, if you extrapolate them up to be 40% of the sample, some weird, weird stuff is going to happen,â€ Harris said. â€œAnyone who does a lot of weighting is really gambling.â€
â€œItâ€™s just money,â€ he continued. â€œI have nothing against them. I get why they [weight their polls] â€” itâ€™s still corners being cut.â€
18 days until Election Day! Hereâ€™s how the 2024 presidential race looks compared to the same date during the 2020 and 2016 elections, according to the RCP poll averages. pic.twitter.com/hUug00Bryi
â€” Matt Margolis (@mattmargolis) October 18, 2024
Though ongoing issues with response bias and overzealous demographic weighting suggest pollsters are still undercounting Trumpâ€™s performance, Republicans should temper their expectations. Harris emphasized that response bias diminishes in the weeks leading up to Election Day. He also cautioned against â€œrecall ballot weighting,â€ where pollsters ask voters about their past votes and adjust their sample based on that information. This approach, he argues, overlooks the fact that â€œno two electorates are ever the same.â€
Pollsters have increasingly employed this technique to ensure Trump supporters are adequately represented in their samples, aiming to correct their previous difficulty in fully capturing the former presidentâ€™s support, according to The New York Times. Some critics say it could lead to an overrepresentation of Republicans in current polling.
Mark Mitchell, the head pollster of Rasmussen Reports, defended the practice in an interview with the Caller.
â€œThereâ€™s a ton of reasons in my state polling why Trump is going to outperform,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m leaning heavily to the recalled vote. That is going to make my numbers less sensitive to low-propensity and first-time voters. And everything weâ€™ve seen tells us that those people are showing up and are raking right.â€
Recall weighting, Mitchell explained, was actually diminishing what he believes to be the full breadth of Trumpâ€™s support in Rasmussenâ€™s polling, adding that the former president would be â€œup four or five points in the national popular voteâ€ without recall weighting.
â€œIâ€™ve been showing Trump [ahead by] 2% in the national popular vote for months now,â€ Mitchell said. â€œThat means heâ€™ll probably sweep all of the battlegrounds, and nobodyâ€™s talking about that.â€
Despite some advances in polling methodology, there remain several indicators that pollsters will again underestimate Trumpâ€™s support, though it seems unlikely that November will vindicate the same level of polling error the â€œbloodbathâ€ narrative suggests â€” the unique dynamics of each election cycle continue to make precise predictions elusive.

title: From #MeToo To #NotYou: Where Are All The Feminist Celebrities On Emhoff?
content:
None of the female celebrities who have endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris have voiced concerns about her husband, Second Gentleman Doug Emhoff, who allegedly has a history of misconduct against women.
Emhoff admitted in August to cheating on his first wife in 2009 with his daughterâ€™s nanny, whom he allegedly impregnated, according to the Daily Mail. Once back on the dating scene, Emhoff, the â€œDad-in-Chief,â€ allegedly slapped his then-girlfriend in a booze-fueled fit of jealous rage in 2012, three friends familiar with the alleged situation told the outlet.
Celebrities like Ariana Grande, Julia Roberts and Billie Eilish have made no mention of the allegations, yet have expressed their support of Harris. Oprah Winfrey also ignored the alleged situation, but has hosted a pro-Harris town hall alongside Jennifer Lopez and Meryl Streep.
Psaki Says Emhoff Reshaping Perception Of Masculinity
NEW: Second Gentleman Doug Emhoff accused of physically assaulting his ex-girlfriend, days after MSNBC host Jen Psaki said Emhoff was â€œreshaping masculinity.â€
According to the Daily Mail, Emhoff hit a woman so hard that she physically spun around.
New details also reveal thatâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/dBPc8rcBL5
â€” Collin Rugg (@CollinRugg) October 2, 2024
Megastar Taylor Swift also endorsed the vice president via Instagram in September, citing abortion rights as one of her top issues. Swift has not used the platform to promote Harris since her original endorsement, nor has she ever acknowledged Emhoffâ€™s alleged behavior.
Other female celebrities, such as Olivia Rodrigo and Jennifer Lawrence, have also pledged their support for Harris, whom they hope will â€œrestore reproductive rights.â€ They too have been silent in the wake of the allegations surfacing.
Some female celebrities, including â€œThe Officeâ€ star Mindy Kaling and Grammy-winning singer Pink, appeared at the Democratic National Convention (DNC) to promote the vice presidentâ€™s campaign in August. Neither of the celebrities have mentioned the allegations against the Second Gentleman. (RELATED: Harris Campaign Holds Rally In Swing State, Invites Pop Star With Ties To Diddy)
Emhoff, who several left-leaning media outlets characterized as a paragon of a new masculinity, was accused of â€œasshole behaviorâ€ and being â€œvery flirtyâ€ at Venable LLP, a law firm he previously managed. Former colleagues of Emhoff who worked there alleged he was also routinely â€œinappropriateâ€ and â€œmisogynisticâ€ during his tenure, the Daily Mail separately reported.
Many of these celebrities offered their labor or intellectual property in service of the Harris campaign â€” BeyoncÃ© granted Harris the rights to her song, â€œFreedom,â€ for campaign advertisements; Anne Hathaway sang at a campaign fundraiser on Broadway; â€œSeinfeldâ€ star Julia Louis Dreyfus promised to be â€œextra involvedâ€ in the Harris campaign â€” but none of them have made any mention of Emhoffâ€™s alleged misdeeds.
Rapper Cardi B, an outspoken critic of President Joe Biden, said Harris should have been the nominee all along. Larger-than-life performer Lizzo joined Harris for a campaign event in Detroit. However, neither of the female musicians appear to have publicly voiced any concerns about the allegations against the Second Gentleman.
Among Harrisâ€™s high-profile supporters are former First Lady Michelle Obama, Jessica Alba, â€œFriendsâ€ star Jennifer Aniston, Jennifer Garner, Glenn Close, â€œScandalâ€ star Kerry Washington, Megan Thee Stallion, pop icon Cher and Barbra Streisand, none of whom have come out against Emhoff.

title: With McConnell MIA, His Potential Replacements Step In To Bolster Battleground Republicans
content:
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell is catching heat on his way out of power for not sufficiently backing battleground-state Republicans with his financial war chest.
The Republican senators vying to replace him are battling to fill the vacuum, dumping big sums of money into key Senate races the GOP will need to win back the majority next week.
Texas Sen. John Cornyn, South Dakota Sen. John Thune and Florida Sen. Rick Scott have all announced theyâ€™re in the race to replace McConnell. Montana Sen. Steve Daines, Chair of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, was also floated as a possible candidate until he removed his name from the hat Wednesday.
â€œIâ€™m appreciative of everybody whoâ€™s asked me to consider it, but Iâ€™m not going to run,â€ Daines said in an interview. â€œIâ€™ve told others Iâ€™m not running for majority leader, and so itâ€™s firm.â€
McConnell has faced particular criticism for giving a financial cold shoulder to Scott and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, who are both facing well-funded Democratic challengers in red states.
In Q3, Cruzâ€™s opponent, Rep. Collin Allred, raised $30.3 million and Cruz raised $21 million. On top of that, last week, a Schumer-backed Democrat PAC made a $5 million ad buy for Allred. Despite this, Cruz remains slightly up in the polls. (RELATED: â€˜Weaponized His Leadershipâ€™: Insurgent Senate GOP Forms Post-McConnell Plan)
As for Scott, in Q3 he raised $4.9 million. His opponent Debbie Mucarsel-Powell raised $15.1 million.
In those two tight and important races, Cornyn and Thune have used their campaign funds to help out Cruz and Scott.
According to a source familiar with Cornynâ€™s political operation, he has raised nearly $850,000 for Scott and more than $715,000 for Cruzâ€™s races cumulatively. Cornyn announced last month that he has raised more than $400M for his colleagues, candidates, the NRSC, and his reelection efforts since 2002.
The source also noted that Cornyn was a special guest on a zoom for Cruzâ€™s super PAC last week.
A source familiar with Thuneâ€™s campaign said Thune has raised six figures for Cruz and Scott through his Joint Fundraising Committees, directly from donors to their campaigns, to the NRSC for both candidates, and at events in D.C. and around the country.
â€œOutside entities affiliated with Thune have transferred $1.75 million to Cruz-affiliated entities and $500K to Scott-affiliated entities,â€ the source familiar told the Caller.
As of September, Thune had raised more than $28 million for Senate candidates and the NRSC and earlier that month Thune told his fellow GOP Senators that he will transfer $4 million from his campaign account to the NRSC. Thune also raised over $1.75 million for the Trump campaign and Republican candidates across the U.S. ahead of two September fundraisers.
Fundraising ability and political prowess come election time are viewed as key skills for the next Senate leader to have, adding extra emphasis to the efforts of Thune, Cornyn and Scott to help the party retake the majority. Scott previously served as Chair of the NRSC himself, a key fundraising position.
Another key factor in the race will be the highly-coveted endorsement of former President Donald Trump, who has yet to weigh in. Tension between Trump and McConnell has been a wedge in the Senate GOP, but the three current contenders to be the next leader have publicly backed Trump against Kamala Harris.
McConnell is the longest-serving party leader of all time in the Senate, and has been serving in the Senate since 1984. According to RealClearPolitics, McConnell is rated as Americansâ€™ most disliked political leader, with favorability ratings lower than President Joe Bidenâ€™s. However, his grip on power within the GOP has remained ironclad for years.
Senate Republicans tell the Caller that whoever becomes the next leader must have a good relationship with Trump, unlike McConnell, in order for them to succeed. (RELATED: Senate Republicans Back Big Change To Prevent Repeat Of McConnell Era)
â€œIf President Trump wins re-election, it will be crucial for him to have a good working relationship with members of Congress â€” especially leadership. It is absurd to argue that his opinion of who those leaders should be is irrelevant. That argument can only be made by people who fear the type of change agent Trump might endorse,â€ Republican Wisconsin Sen. Ron Johnson told the Daily Caller.
Another U.S. Senator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, told the Caller that Senate Republicansâ€™ main worry should be having someone like McConnell take his place. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: â€˜This Is Our Opportunityâ€™ â€” Top GOP Senators Game McConnellâ€™s Ouster After Botched Border Deal)
â€œMitch walks out while refusing to help Ted Cruz and Rick Scott in tight races that could determine who gets a Senate majority. He badmouths and undermines Trump right before the election. If either of the Johns want the top job, my concern is who will be a team player, and who will be McConnell part 2 and continue to sabotage the party,â€ the Republican senator said.
Despite saying they back Trump, both Thune and Cornyn have voting records that resemble McConnellâ€™s. They have voted for most continuing resolutions and omnibus bills with McConnell, but against the Inflation Reduction Act and the Small Business COVID relief act of 2022 during the last Congress.
The pair also voted for the supplemental legislation that contained Ukraine funding during this Congress, and havenâ€™t been shy about voting for massive appropriations bills. A majority of the bills they voted against were almost completely along party lines. The three also voted in favor of the 2024 NDAA, which extended FISA powers until April. All three have also been consistent supporters of providing additional aid to Ukraine. (RELATED: EXCLUSIVE: GOP Civil War Deepens As Senators Claim McConnell Threw Partyâ€™s Voters â€˜Under The Busâ€™ On Ukraine, Border)
The GOP Senate leadership election will take place on Nov. 13.

title: â€˜Shockingâ€™ Number Of Americans Believe Speech Can Be â€˜Violence,â€™ Poll Finds
content:
A large majority of Americans believe words can be equated to physical violence, a poll released Thursday found.
In total, 80% of respondents at least slightly agreed with the statement that â€œwords can be violence,â€ while 22% said it describes their thoughts â€œcompletely,â€ according to an October poll by the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE), which it described as â€œshocking.â€ Only 12% of Gen Z respondents disagreed that speech could be violence.
â€œEquating words with violence trivializes actual physical harm, shuts down conversations, and even encourages real violence by justifying the use of force against offensive speech,â€ Greg Lukianoff, FIRE President and CEO, said in a press release. â€œFree speech isnâ€™t violence, itâ€™s the best alternative to violence ever invented.â€
Women were more likely to believe words can be equated to violence, with 86% responding in the affirmative compared to 73% of men, according to the press release. Democrats were more likely to agree with the comparison, totaling 89% compared to 73% of Republicans and 72% of independents.
Nearly 90% of Americans surveyed said they believe they should have the right to speak freely during a public comment session, over 70% said they believe they should have the right to criticize public officials during council meetings and 55% believe they should have the right to post mocking videos of political candidates to social media, FIRE found.
Many Americans in the poll reported having to censor their speech, with 85% doing so over the past month alone, while 38% are at least slightly worried about losing their job if someone complains about something they have said, the poll found.
Around 64% of respondents also said that free speech in the U.S. is heading in the wrong direction, with just over 40% saying the right to free speech is â€œnot veryâ€ or â€œnot at allâ€ secure, according to the poll.
Events such as protests have raised questions nationally about what is considered free speech and where to draw the line. While countless protests nationwide have grown into violence and had to be forcefully broken apart, one federal judge recently found that an anti-Israel group had grounds to sue university officials for limiting their ability to protest. (RELATED: Harvard Professor Argues Disinviting Offensive Speakers Is â€˜A Form Of Expressionâ€™)
The poll was conducted Oct. 4 through 11 and surveyed 1,000 individuals with a margin of error of 3%.

title: â€˜It Doesnâ€™t Affect Meâ€™: Trump Reveals Who Wasnâ€™t â€˜Thrilledâ€™ About His Team Up With RFK Jr.
content:
Former President Donald Trump told podcaster Joe Rogan that pharmaceutical executives were not â€œthrilledâ€ that he teamed up with former independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. during a Friday interview.
Kennedy endorsed Trump and announced the suspension of his campaign on Aug. 23, ten months after launching his independent bid, following his split with Democrats over issues including censorship, the war in Ukraine, illegal immigration, the partyâ€™s failure to hold primary debates and primary rules that gave President Joe Biden an advantage. When Rogan asked if anyone had urged Trump not to work with Kennedy, the former president revealed some pushback from pharmaceutical company executives. (RELATED: â€˜Why Not?â€™: Trump Tells Rogan Heâ€™ll Use Tariffs To Eliminate Income Tax, Make America â€˜Richâ€™)
WATCH:
â€œI would say that â€” and you know, I think in many ways theyâ€™ve done a good job and in many ways theyâ€™ve done a bad job â€” but I would say that Big Pharma wasnâ€™t thrilled when they heard that,â€ Trump said, adding, â€œIâ€™ve actually always gotten along very well with him [Kennedy], Iâ€™ve known him a long time.â€
The social media platform Instagram banned Kennedy over his views on vaccines in February 2021, and ABC News edited out a portion of an interview where he discussed the COVID-19 vaccines. Kennedy said Trump would â€œmake America healthy againâ€ during an August interview with Fox News host Shannon Bream.
â€œHeâ€™s a different kind of a guy,â€ Trump said of Kennedy. â€œHeâ€™s very smart, great guy, and heâ€™s very sincere about this. I mean, he really is. He thinksâ€” we spend a fortune on pesticides, on all this stuff, and then you end upâ€” that chart is a terrible chart, the one previous. Itâ€™s such a bad chart when you look at where we are compared to other countries that donâ€™t spend ten cents.â€
The chart showed life expectancy compared to health expenditure per capita for a number of countries, including the United States, which fell largely behind other nations despite spending more on health care and services per capita.
â€œIâ€™ve had some people who arenâ€™t exactly thrilled,â€ Trump said, regarding Kennedyâ€™s involvement with his campaign. â€œIt doesnâ€™t affect me,â€ Trump said about the criticism.
